We are still here waiting orders, we are taking things easy too. We rose at 7.30 & breakfast at 8 o'clock. It seemed ridiculous to get up half an hour before breakfast, because we have no water to wash anything. We can get enough for a shave from the water cart, but that is all. The people who were in this camp "got the wind up"& blew in all the wells, burned the disabled planes, & left nothing for the enemy except the accommodation. Consequently we have a drought. But it is raining heavily tonight. We may catch a little from the roof. We fell in on parade at 9.30, our rifles were inspected & then we were detailed to wash the tool-carts & limbers. These cursed things are more nuisance than they are worth. We did not take long to do it owing ot the scarcity of water, & what we did have was muddy. We then examined an aeroplane left in one of the hangers. An aeroplane has wonderful workmanship in it, everything built for lightness & strength, but nevertheless the planes built at present are huge & heavy. This plane was a single seater, & had a Lewis & Vicars machine guns in it. The Lewis gun was fixed above the plane & the Vicars was inside worked & timed by the shaft as it fired between the blades of the tractor. But this plane is by no means the best I have seen. After lunch at noon, we had permission to visit the village. We went, but there was absolutely nothing but empty houses & filth. Some of the froggies were left but they were packed up ready to move. We soon left it. On our way home, we had a look at two tanks which were lying near by the road. I shall not attempt to describe a tank inside, beyond the fact that it is a mass of machines & guns. There is absolutely no room to move once the crew is inside. The mere look of them is an emblem of strength. We have heard from the Tommies that the Tommy divisions which were opposed by Fritz, first just took to their heels. They left everything & in one place, they left over 200 stretcher cases outside a dressing station. There was apparantly a stampede& for miles back, we have met Tommies, who have lost their battalions. The enemy is checked now & it seems that it will be a repetition of last years battle of the Somme. The place where we are now camped, is known as Clairfait. We had an issue of bread to-night, five men to a small loaf, which pans out to less than two slices for 24 hours. We are now in the Somme, known for its scarcity.

We rose at 7 o'clock to get ready for the road again. The whole division is on the move & it really is an eye opener to see the roadsofonecontinuous stream of men, horses and motors. Where do they all come from is the main question, because we all know where they are going. We vacated our quarters at 9.30, to allow another unit to enter. We started to move at 10.30. It was dull & cool, wh. seemed very promising for marching, but before we had gone very far it began to rain. All along the road were groups of Tommy A.S.C., anywhere where it was temorily possible to dump their stores & camp. This last move has been quite different to what we have seen yet, consquently no provision of any kind has been made. We came along six miles nearer to the line, but we are in no particular village. We first landed in the blacksmiths shop of the R.F.C., & the filth was awful. However the rain came thro the roof in several places, so now we are in a hut wh. the Tommies have just left. This came belongs to the R.F.C., but they have deserted it. We have received biscuits for rations to-day, wh. I presume is the beginning of them until we get more settled. We are not far off the line now, & ready to move anywhere. This is a true phase of olden warefare where we have to rely on the rapid movement of troops.We had a hot dinner to-night, wh. is always welcome; it is a boisterous night, wind, rain & cold & have to thank our lucky stars that we have a roof over our heads. This & next month are usually wet, & suppose more will follow. We managed to get a paper five days old, wh. was the beginning of the offensive & we devoured it. At present, we have had no news at all & people in Australia get every detail within 24 hours. The country is more open here & it is possible to see for miles over beautifully cultivated fields, & sprouting crops. Many of the crops have been destroyed owing to the necessity of having to dig trenches. You will notice that my writing varies considerably but that is only due to the varied positions in wh. I have written this. At present, I'm in the prone.

28.3.18

Duly at 7.0 pm we left the camp at Reninhelst . We left as a field company leaves when on the move. Officers mounted, cyclists of section led off, followed by section sappers & tools carts: Headquarters brought up the rear. We left 240 sappers and drivers, 30 bicycles, & 71 horses and limbers, pontoons etc. We occupied about 600 yds of road. We marched to Houputre & arrived there at 9 o'clock. It was a fair distance & we did it on one spell of ten minutes. We entrained at the latter place. A part of pioneers loaded the train with the waggons & carts, & the drivers, the horses. We were packed into cattle trucks, 32 men in each. It was a frightfully cold night, & we dreaded the journey. We had a cup of tea at 10.30 & left at 11.45. The floor of the truck had spaces of half an inch between the boards. We had an awful night, & my feet were like two blocks of ice the whole time. We made a cup of cocoa by getting some hot water from the engine. We arrived at Mondicourt at 12 o'clock; it was blowing a gale of cold wind.Had a cup of tea wh. we managed to make behind a shed, & left for the road at 1.45 am. Everything & everybody was in a bustle. Cars of wounded & lorries with all sorts of stores lined the road. We passed Americans digging in & deserted villages & eventually reached Vauschelles where we are camping for the night, we arrived here at 5 o'clock. My feet were so sore that I could hardly stand after our 9 mile march. We were



lined up at 9.50 & we were marched in front, & the whole parade was drawn up before the Major. The orderly officer read out routine orders, then the Major read a letter from Major General Hobbs, to the effect that we were entering the most decisive battle of the war, &that it was everybody's duty from commander down, to do his utmost to uphold the reputation of the division wh.had a record of divisions etc. etc. The Major then spoke of the reputation of the company, wh. had taken two years to win, and not to lose it etc. We were then broken off to clean up the camp,& thetransport moved off. It looked fine & like a new transport, & the horses were very fresh. We had lunch at 11.15 and moved off in shell fire formation at 12.30. We waited for the light railway at Kemmel wh. was to leave at 1 o'clock but nobody ever dreamed of it coming before it did, at 2 o'clock. We bundled into low, open trucks, and set out for Reninhelst. It turned out a beautiful sunny day & to see all the troops being taken from this front in the railways, seemed like a south coast line in holiday time. Trains passed along all night & all day, & it has been one huge exodus. All motor lorries have gone, and the place seems quite forsaken. We passed thro ploughed fields & sprouting crops. It is a new order that every unit must plough an area ofland & cultivate grain. This applies to the transport lines mostly, as they have the horses to do the work. The first operation is clearing the barbed wire, & it is wonderful how the place can be cleared of this treacherous material. There are piles of wire lying all over the country. When we arrived at Reninhelst Terminus we had to walk for half an hour to this camp. We are here, apparently comfortable, for the night. We arried at 3.30, had dinner at 4.0 pm. Then I had a wash in a neighbouring dam & settle down for a rest. We have heard that the French have out-flanked the Boche, but the news is very scanty and indefinite.

It was too cold to be enviable, too cold even to make my mind &imagination travel back to warmer climes. The only bare sandwas that where the snow has been licked off by the waves. The bath was next, paid two francs, & upstairs. A clean bathroom, an immaculate enamel bath, & a clean towel crisp with dryness having every prospect of a good rubdown. What a difference to our pig-pool washing place, & my damp greasy towel. I lay in the bath for half an hour and soaked. When I came out, I felt as though I didn't want to look at anything in case I got black again. I gazed with envious eye at the camouflaged steamers in the harbour. All the steamers are painted in various colours, anyhow & everyhow, but that did not take away the desire to visit my antipods. I then spent an hour or two at the pictures wh. were quite good. I paid an exorbitant price of 2d. for a programme, wh. was a single sheet of common blue paper, a facsimile to those circulars wh. are thrown at our doors by dirty little urchins, wh. urge us to vote "No". At 6.30 I set out in search of food; firstly to buy bread, & secondly to temporily nourish myself. I bought the bread & tuckedit under my coat & away. The bakers do not wrap paper round the food, but each buyer is supposed to provide a basket or other equivalent. I walked down the street until I found a newspaper boy, who wanted to sell me an English paper for 2Â½d.& he didn't understand that a French 1d. paper wd do the trick. I then sat myself down in a restaurant and called for dinner. All was well until the last course came & heaven only knows what it was. I gave it best after two mouthfuls, & I now hope that it was not some frog or snail concoction. It was then time to look for the lorry, wh. I found quite easily: the trip home was notthe most comfortable, but I landed home about 9.30, to find half a dozen Australian letters.

I always wear, together with felt soles & paper inside, they get very tired & sore owing to the short steps one has to take: it also affects the muscles ofthe upper part of the leg. On parade I was told to fall out, that my leave to Boulogne had been granted. I returned to my billet to put the finishing touches to my dress. I turned up for my pass at the orderly room in due course & was on my way by 11.30. It was a beautifully fine and sunny day, and I imagined Fritz visiting Boulogne at night. I caught the train as it leaves earlier than the lorries. The trains are very old-fashioned in these parts: the platforms in the first place are only about a foot above the rails, wh. means that passengers have to climb into the carriages on two steps. We complain about our tram-car steps, but if you were to see the women getting in & out with babies & parcels in these parts, you would smile at our own. Our train also had three engines, antidiluvian at that, for what reason I could not find out, but guessed that if one broke down there shd always be another on hand: "slow & sure" must be their motto, interpreted by nine miles per hour & three engines.At a certain station en route, the civilian passengers have to get out & show their passports & tickets. Entry.9: After dinner I went to Samerwith Gormly. We tried to obtain bread, but it was impossible. We visited the several canteens & bakeries, but our search was quite futile. We learned there, that some of the infantry were dividing their loaves into five & six rations, wh, accounted for the wild rush at the restaurants. I could not even purchase a paper tonight, so do not know how the world goes.
Entry.10: More snow fell during the night, but fortunately the temperatureis not very low. I gavein my name yesterday as one of the two to go on leave to Boulogne. I remained behind in the billet while the section went off to Samur at 9.30 for a bath. I waited until 11.15 when it was time to report at the orderly room for passes & inspection. On arriving there, we were told that all leave had been stopped, as there were five men A.W.L. It was very disappointing to have been told so late: however the C.S.M. told us to put in an application to our O.C. in writing, wh. I did at once, hoping to obtain leave tomorrow. We returned to the billet & found that the section had returned also. The bath was a failure, conveniences unsatisfactory, water was cold & there was no change of clothes.
